bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, March 20, 1942

div1.p: Hench is glad to have Wood's reference to the Ashburn history of the Army Medical Corps. He comments on an illustration that has been prepared for her book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, March 20, 1942
div1.p:
I am disappointed that your book will not appear shortly but have
no doubt that you can utilize the extra time to great advantage. I shall
be delighted to see any manuscript changes you may make and if I don't have
to rush it back I will be glad to go over it in much more detail.

I am glad to have the Ashburn reference. We have it in the library
and I hadn't got around to reading it. Your one sentence was priceless in
which you said that your book started out as a children's book but “as the
subject got tougher the kiddies got older.”

I wouldn't waste my time on Carroll. It would only be another un-
pleasant experience, I am afraid. I had two very unhappy experiences with him.
He is something of a psychopath and only time and God's grace will solve his
problem!

Maybe your illustrator who planned to have a picture of “an under-
clad nifty kneeling in the street” is to try to make the book appeal to
young boys of eighteen to twenty! I am eager to see that particular picture.

closer.seg:
P. S. When I wrote the above, my secretary looked at me accusingly
and, realizing that I hadn't quite passed the menopause, said, “Why do you
limit the appeal to boys of eighteen to twenty?”
